            REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF032590-ESTONIA - DISTRICT HEATING,TF031918-ESTONIA - ENERGY SECTOR

abstracts.cdata!:
The District Heating Rehabilitation
            Project's overall achievements of the objectives are
            judged to be satisfactory. The project was demand-driven
            throughout Estonia, i.e., the Government, Eesti Energia,
            municipalities and district heating (DH) companies wanted
            and supported the project. Thus, it showed a strong level of
            ownership by the Borrower and project beneficiaries.
            Moreover, it came at the right time, addressing high
            priority issues shortly after re-independence. There were a
            number of valuable lessons: 1) The demand forecasts of the
            project were overly-optimistic. In cities where DH is facing
            unfair competition from alternative heating options,
            consideration should be given to specifying areas where DH
            is the required heating option until the factors leading to
            the unfair competition are removed, in order to preserve DH
            demand. Demand forecast analysis should also consider the
            results of social assessments to help forecast
            consumers' reactions and responses to possible tariff
            increases and the ability to measure and regulate heat
            consumption. 2) Appropriate tariff policies play an
            important role in maintaining DH consumers and thus the
            viability of DH systems. Two-tier tariff policies allow for
            the transparent pricing of DH based on fixed and variable
            costs and thus allow DH companies to charge for actual costs
            of supply. 3) It is highly important to properly assess
            risks associated with the potential for competition from
            gas, or other alternatives, to DH.
